go up.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to increase in price, amount, level etc
go up.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Blood-sugar levels go up as you digest food.
Unemployment in the country has gone up by a million.
Spending on research went up from $426 million to $461 million.
go up from something to something
go up.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if a building or sign goes up, it is built or fixed into place
go up.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: It was a lovely place before all these new houses went up.
go up.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to explode, or be destroyed in a fire
go up.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: He had left the gas on and the whole kitchen went up.
The whole building went up in flames.
go up.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if a shout or a cheer goes up, people start to shout or cheer
go up.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: A great cheer went up from the audience.
go up.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to go from one place to another, especially to a place that is further north, or to a town or city from a smaller place
go up.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: We’re going up to Scotland next weekend.
He went up to the farm to get some eggs.
go up.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: if lights go up, they become brighter
go up.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: when the lights went up at the end of the performance
go up.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to begin studying at a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge University
